speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to continue my remarks today on Bill C-60.
This is important legislation, legislation which deals with federal-provincial tax arrangements as well as the health and education transfers to the province, that is the Established Programs Financing, the money that the federal government gives to provinces to spend on education and health.
I am pleased to speak today on these two areas because these are important areas to my riding, as I am sure they are to all ridings across this country. They are areas that the government should be making priorities.
But it is really doing the opposite because what it is doing is reducing the growth of transfer payments to the
Government Orders
provinces for education and for health. Tb give you the figures, Mr. Speaker, these cuts the government has made result in a reduction of $9 billion by 1995 according to the Canadian Association of University Teachers. That is for education alone.
The health transfers will be reduced almost $20 billion by 1995. That is the record of the government where it has cut the growth of funding to education and health.
Let us look at what this Conservative government promised before coming to power. When he was opposition leader, the present Prime Minister said, and these are his exact words: "We are committed to sustaining the current federal financial commitment according to the formula set out in the 1977 agreement. We believe that financing post-secondary education is an important priority for both levels of government".
That is what the Prime Minister said when he was Leader of the Opposition. Unfortunately he has not carried through with that commitment because what we have had are changes in that formula. In fact we had one in 1986 and another change in 1990 which amounted to a reduction of money going to the provinces.
I also want to put on record a remark that was made by the present Minister for International Trade before he became the Minister of Finance. He told the House of Commons in 1982 when he was speaking on the established programs funding: "The Established Programs Financing reductions could have disastrous effects on universities and colleges, on hospital funding, and on the operation of hospitals. Let us not make hospitals, universities, and colleges a battleground between the federal government and the provincial government. Let us solve these problems, not on the backs of the hospitals and universities. Let us solve those problems outside the arena". That is a quote from the Minister for International Trade when he was in the opposition.
Clearly the government has not kept its word. Here we have cuts. As I said we had a change in the formula in 1986 and another one in 1990.
The government is doing exactly what the Minister for International Tirade said it should not do. What it is doing is solving its financial problems on the backs of the

March 20, 1992
Government Orders
hospitals, the universities, and the colleges, and it is doing that by the cuts it provided in the formula for Established Programs Financing, which is the money to come to the provinces for education and health.
If we look at the effects that these cuts are having on the provinces, it means if, for example, the province of Prince Edward Island gets less money, it has less money to give the universities. In our case it would be the University of Prince Edward Island. At that university, as I am sure at all universities, tuition fees have increased tremendously. In fact, at the University of Prince Edward Island the tuition fee has gone up 57 per cent from 1985 to 1991. Over a period of six years tuition fees have gone up 57 per cent.
As I said, the government is giving the provinces less money, yet the cost of education is going up tremendously. We also have to look at the record of this government and the student loans program.
As I have just said, in my province of Prince Edward Island tuition fees have gone up 57 per cent, yet this government has not changed the amount of money given under the student loans program since 1984.
I have been calling on this government to look at that program since I was elected in 1988. I have tabled a private members' bill in this House. Hopefully that bill will be drawn and will force the government to look at this whole area. The student loans program as it stands today is very inadequate.
Another factor that will affect our education is that fewer people will be able to go to university. We will have people with all kinds of ability who simply cannot afford to get a university degree.
I am not the only one saying this. For example, in a Globe and Mail article of March 7, 1992, the headline says it all: "Only wealthy need apply". Students are graduating $25,000 to $30,000 in debt. People with ability but little money steer themselves away from a university education. According to the president of St. Thomas University in New Brunswick, and I quote: "We are getting to the point where only the wealthy and the near wealthy will be able to afford university education".
Another effect of federal education cutbacks, of course, is reduced competitiveness. This government talks about competitiveness, but we do not need any more talk. What we need is action.
This government pays big money for studies like the $1 million that was spent on the Porter study on competitiveness. Business and labour leaders are saying that the most important factor in improving Canada's competitiveness is better education, training and human resource policies.
I see my time is running out. I had many things I wanted to say about this legislation. I want to conclude by saying that it is very obvious that the federal government has not lived up to its pre-election promises with regard to the transfer payments. The effects of these cuts are being felt everywhere, from the factory floor to the university campus and the hospital ward.
Canadians expect better and Canadians deserve better.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to take part in this debate on Bill C-60 now before the House. As everyone knows, this bill tabled in the House on February 20 concerns equalization programs.
Needless to say, these equalization programs are the cornerstone of our Canadian economic union. In 1992-93, the government will make contributions totalling $8.5 billion to the provinces, and on the whole have not provinces will profit most from this.
It is important to remember that at a Ministers of Finance meeting on January 30 the federal Minister of Finance proposed a two-year extension of the equalization program, from April 1, 1992 to March 31, 1994. This program extension would entail an increase of about $400 million for the provinces in 1992-93; about half of this, some $200 million, would become permanent increases, while the rest, some $200 million also, would be temporary benefits.
As we all know, the program renewal proposal is composed of three different sections: a wider tax base, the maintenance of the equalization ceiling for 1992-93; and the elimination of some technical irritant concerning the interaction of equalization programs and Established
March 20, 1992

Programs Financing. This is of course one more program involving federal transfers to provinces. All Canadian provinces will receive benefits under the measures being discussed here today.
It might be important to discuss the components of this program.

The equalization as proposed in the bill for 1992-93 would be in the order of $31 million for Newfoundland, $5 million for P.E.I., some $35 million for Nova Scotia, $39 million for New Brunswick, $198 million for the province of Quebec, some $55 million for Manitoba, and $60 million for Saskatchewan. Of course, the provinces of Ontario and British Columbia do not qualify under the provisions that I have just enumerated.
The interaction with the Established Programs Financing needs to be raised a bit as well, I think. There is a recognition, of course, that there are provincial concerns about the interaction between the Established Programs Financing and the equalization calculations by ensuring that the value of the tax transfer and the determination of the program entitlements reflect the equalization ceiling estimated benefits to the province to be more than $200 million. This is a one-time payment for retroactive effects.
I do not want to take much more time of the House speaking to this bill. Because we are talking about transfers to provinces, maybe this is an appropriate time as well to raise the matter of other transfers and how they impact upon us as Canadians. In other areas we discussed the measures not that long ago in the House of Commons, areas of transfers to the provinces for the purposes of health care and social welfare. In those two cases, my province, the province of Ontario, and the hon. member who will be speaking momentarily, his province of British Columbia, those provinces really got a raw deal from the federal government because some of those transfers were frozen or at least they were capped to a maximum three per cent increase.
I think the President of the Treasury Board is nodding in agreement when I say this. In my own province of Ontario as a result of the recession, of course which was authored by the federal government and expanded upon
Government Orders
courtesy of the provincial NDP, they are very busy, as you know, chasing jobs away to the United States. Since they have taken over the provincial government, unfortunately, for many residents of my province, the NDP has had some success at chasing jobs away to south of the border.
Due to those two factors, we have an increasingly high number of people in Ontario who are on welfare, coupled with the effects of Bill C-21. Members will remember the notorious Bill C-21 of last session which cut back on the number of weeks that a person could get unemployment insurance. All of those things together have expanded the number of people who are on welfare in my province and elsewhere in Canada. In my province, there is a general cap on the Canada Assistance Plan transfers to those provinces.
That has made it such that it is becoming more and more difficult, particularly in a recession to take care of the increasing number of people who have fallen off not only the job market, but also they have fallen off the unemployment insurance benefits and have fallen on to the welfare rolls.
The unfortunate side effect of all of that has been that to a fair degree now we see municipal tax increases and to a degree, provincial tax increases, to satisfy the shortfall that was caused by the fact that the federal government put a ceiling or a cap on Canada Assistance Plan transfers to those provinces.

So, Mr. Speaker, the picture is certainly not rosy in our province. But being here to speak about the equalization issue, I thought I would take the opportunity to remind the government opposite of its role in the effective financing, not only of the equalization program, but also of the Canada Assistance Plan which, in my province, for example, is in serious difficulty.
Therefore, Mr. Speaker, I too wish that, at this eleventh hour, the government opposite would come back to its senses and at some time in the future would choose to make more generous contributions so that we can take care of those less fortunate people from the province that I represent here in the House of Commons as the member for Glengarry-Prescott-Russell.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I too, wish to participate in the debate on Bill C-60, an act to amend the Federal-Provincial Fiscal Arrangements and Federal Post-Secondary Education and Health Contributions Act. I am very pleased that the President of Treasury Board is in the House. I hope he will take note of some of the concerns that we have, especially a member from British Columbia with regard to this bill.
Really, what has happened-and of course I realize this is a housekeeping bill that the government is bringing in with regard to equalization payments and fiscal arrangements with the provinces-is that the government has systematically passed the burden of the national debt on to the provinces. There is no question about that as we look back and see the capping of the programs in British Columbia, in Ontario and in Alberta.
According to the programs the government brought in, it identified these provinces as being the richer provinces. Therefore it felt that it could cap them and let them fend for themselves.
At the same time as this is going on, changes were being made to the Unemployment Insurance Act. The government opted out of that program and put the total burden on the workers and on the companies. This again hits the provinces, every province, because it takes that extra money out of those communities. It comes directly out of the provinces and out of the municipalities.
The capping of the medicare and the post-secondary education programs again takes the money directly out of those provinces and the provinces have to come up with the extra moneys in order to provide those programs. That affects the municipalities and goes all the way through the line. As these things take effect those areas are affected.
I want to talk a little about the pressure tactics the government is using on these provinces in order to get them to come on line. It brought in the GST, and 80 per cent of the Canadian public does not want it. The GST is having tremendous effects on the provinces across Canada.
The federal government is trying to harmonize this program, and I want to use an example. In my riding I have three border crossings: one at Roosevelt, one at Creston, and one at Yahk, British Columbia. People are crossing that border not because they are getting better deals, not because of anything. Almost everyone who contacts me and to whom I have talked says it is in protest to the kinds of policies this government has brought in.
That affects the small businesses in my riding. That affects every portion of the riding. Coming back to fiscal arrangements, the government is trying to bring them about. But it is causing more problems with the policies it is adopting.
The government talks about competitiveness. It says that we must be competitive in this market because we have entered into a free trade agreement. Goodness knows the majority in my riding did not support the free trade agreement, but it is certainly suffering because of that free trade agreement.
Rather than a free trade agreement we would have preferred to see a sector-by-sector agreement that made more common sense than what this government has done in the over-all agreement.
Students are affected by it. The government talks about being competitive in the free trade market it is talking about. Yet it is systematically cutting back and stopping our students from being able to enter the system to upgrade their skills and produce the kind of competitiveness the government says will be required to meet the needs of the future.
In every field the government has put its finger on, it has created deeper and bigger problems. It has said to the provinces: "You must come on line with us". It is offering them a goody: "If you come and harmonize the GST with us, we will collect your provincial sales tax".
Those are the kinds of discussions that go on with each province with regard to border crossings and so on. That is not the way to bring people on stream. That is not the way to listen to people.
The government should have listened to the people, not brought in the goods and services tax, and looked at it in a more equitable way. During the GST debate-and
March 20, 1992

this affects the provinces-the minister said that the manufacturers' tax would be removed.
Did we actually see a decrease in the price of automobiles? Did we actually see a decrease in what the consumer was buying? I did not notice it. The people in my riding did not notice it. But they certainly noticed the extra 13 per cent, the 7 per cent GST and the 6 per cent tax on top of that.
The government is now talking about reaching equalization agreements and a housekeeping bill to bring about these kinds of things with the provinces for another two years.
It has not treated the provinces fairly, especially Ontario, Alberta and British Columbia. It has singled them out and it has systematically, without any prior consultation with the provinces, introduced the bill into this House and brought about changes for those three provinces which are unworthy. We said so at the time and it certainly created an extra burden on the provinces because of that decision.
I heard the Liberal member who spoke just prior to me talk about the situation in Ontario. He said that the Ontario government is driving jobs to the United States. Nothing could be further from the truth. Everyone knows that the free trade agreement is the cause of what is going on across that border. Everyone knows that had the Liberals stood up and fought against the free trade agreement, stood up and said so at the time and continued fighting it, this would not be happening. No, they flip-flop back and forth because the large corporations said to them: "Oh, you cannot do this". So do not blame the Ontario government for driving jobs out of the country. Take a look in your own backyard and to the kinds of things that went on. Stand up in this House and fight for the people of Ontario instead of blaming the Ontario government.
Stand up against the free trade agreement and let us bring in an agreement sector by sector. Let us not put our dairy workers at risk. Let us not put our farmers at risk. Let us not put other workers at risk because of an over-all free trade agreement. Again we come back to the provinces because every province is affected. Every piece of legislation that this government has tinkered with has caused great concern to the provinces.
Government Orders
It has caused the provinces to try to pick up the slack. The unemployment insurance program is a prime example as to how it affects the provinces. When you take the money out of those areas, you hurt the people that are involved. The government also says that it is trying to re-educate people. If it really wanted to be competitive, if it really wanted to educate the people, it would be contributing today one-third of the cost of the unemployment insurance program to ensure that the kind of educational programs, the kind of technologies that our students and our workers are going to need would be there. It has withdrawn its contributions to that program and made it totally the program of the workers and the employers.
If the government really wants to upgrade the education and the training techniques of the Canadian people and the Canadian workers, it has to get back into that program, start participating in it and start to build the kind of country we are going to need for the future.
The government is talking about a free trade agreement with Mexico and we are not even allowed to participate in it. As the opposition members we are not even allowed to know what kind of discussions are taking place. I want to say to the government on that issue and to all the provinces that will be affected by this, that it is going to affect every one of us. Because if it makes that agreement, the government will also suffer.
While we are talking about equalization payments, while we are talking about harmonizing, let us really look at the broad scope of what this government is doing.
